request_pathways.name: Proliance Surgeons ROI authorization form (PHWE version)
Proliance Surgeons ROI authorization form (ProOrtho version)

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient downloads a generic HIPAA authorization form designed for third-party disclosure, fills in their own name as the recipient, and faxes it to the practice.

red_flags: Generic third-party authorization form used for patient self-access with no dedicated Right of Access pathway
Image-only scan version (form-1) hosted on subsidiary site is completely inaccessible to assistive technology
Subsidiary form (form-3) cites California CMIA instead of Washington State law
bright_spots: Concise single-page format covering all essential authorization elements
Sensitive information categories (HIV, mental health, STDs, substance use) properly separated with individual opt-in per Washington State law
Patient rights section written in accessible first-person language
Datavant online portal mentioned as alternative request pathway on medical records page

findability.rationale: Level 4: Easy to find with basic navigation or a simple search — web search immediately surfaced multiple forms, and the main medical records page links directly to the primary form with no bot blocking or creative searching required.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 2: Primarily a paper workflow — the best available form (form-2/form-4) has a text layer but zero fillable fields, requiring print, handwrite, and fax/mail submission; form-1 is an image-only scan with no text layer at all.

content_design.rationale: Level 4: Well-organized with minor clarity issues — clean two-section structure (My Authorization / My Rights), plain first-person language, logical flow, and good scope granularity, with only minor issues like dense expiration language and a marketing checkbox that could confuse patients.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the process but it wasn't designed for them — the generic authorization form requires patients to designate themselves as 'recipient' with full address, offers no format/delivery preferences, and makes no reference to HIPAA Right of Access or individual access timelines.

compliance.rationale: Level 4: Minor ambiguities but nothing materially impeding — no notarization, no excessive fees, proper sensitive-information opt-in for Washington State law, clear revocation instructions, though the form conflates § 164.508 authorization with § 164.524 access and subsidiary form-3 cites wrong state law.

overall.summary: Proliance Surgeons provides easily findable, concise authorization forms with clean content design, but the lack of fillable fields and reliance on a generic third-party authorization form for patient self-access significantly limit the patient experience.
